sections.title: You can apply for Alternative Dispute Resolution

fields.infoText:
We will now ask you for more details about your dispute.

If your application is accepted, these details will allow our mediators to better understand your situation. 

This will help them work together with you to share information and reach a resolution.

sections.title: You cannot apply for this service yet

fields.infoText:
You need to wait for the review to finish then appeal to the tribunal. This appeal must be accepted before you can apply for Alternative Dispute Resolution.

[Find out how to appeal to the tax tribunal](https://www.gov.uk/tax-tribunal).

sections.title: You need to make an appeal before using this service

fields.infoText:
Once you have had an appeal accepted, you can use this service.

[Find out how to appeal to the tax tribunal](https://www.gov.uk/tax-tribunal).

sections.title: Can HMRC communicate with you by email while you use this service?

fields.label: Can HMRC communicate with you by email while you use this service?
fields.helpText: Because email cannot be guaranteed 100% secure, you need to understand and accept the risks before sending and receiving email.
fields.errorMessage: Select whether you want to be contacted using your email address
choices: Yes, I want to use email
No, I do not want to use email
optionHelpText:
By selecting yes, you confirm that: 


*you understand and accept the risks of using email 


*you agree that financial information can be sent by email 


*you agree that attachments can be sent by email


We will use the email you provided in this application unless you tell us otherwise.

Before you continue, select 'Why does HMRC ask me about email?' to read and understand how we use email.
We will use letter or telephone if we need to contact you.

fields.label: Why does HMRC ask me about email?
fields.infoText:
**HMRC asks for your consent for these reasons:**


*confidentiality and privacy – there’s a risk that emails sent over the internet may be intercepted

*confirming your identity – we only communicate with established contacts at their correct email addresses

*there is no guarantee that an email received over an insecure network, like the internet, hasn’t been altered during transit

*attachments could contain a virus or malicious code



**How we can reduce the risks**

*HMRC desensitises information, for example by only quoting part of any unique reference numbers

*We can also encrypt information

*If you want to encrypt information, we can discuss how you can do this while still providing the information we need



**If you decide not to use email**

You may prefer that we do not respond by email, for example because other people have access to your email account. If so, we can respond by an alternative method. We‘ll agree this with you either by telephone, fax or in writing via post.


**How we use your agreement**

Your confirmation will be held on file and will apply to future email correspondence. We will review the agreement at regular intervals to ensure there are no changes.



**Opting out**

You can opt out of using email at any time by contacting your mediator once you have been accepted to use the service.


**Adding other contacts**

You can add other names and email addresses who you want us to use email with, for example, your staff or your representative. Contact your mediator once you have been accepted to use the service.



[Find more information on HMRC's privacy policy](www.gov.uk/help/privacy-policy).

sections.title: Enter your enquiry reference

fields.label: Enter your enquiry reference
fields.helpText: This is called 'HMRC ref' or 'Your ref' on correspondence about this dispute. It is a combination of letters and numbers, for example CFS-123456 or CFSS-1234567.

sections.title: Enter your VAT Registration Number

fields.label: Enter your VAT Registration Number
fields.helpText: This is 9 numbers, sometimes with ‘GB’ at the start, for example 123456789 or GB123456789. You can find it on your VAT registration certificate.

sections.title: Enter your Unique Taxpayer Reference

fields.label: Enter your Unique Taxpayer Reference
fields.helpText: This is 10 numbers, for example 1234567890. It will be on tax returns and other letters about Corporation Tax or Self Assessment. It may be called 'reference', 'UTR' or 'official use'.

sections.title: Enter your employer PAYE reference

fields.label: Enter your employer PAYE reference
fields.helpText: This is a 3 digit tax office number, a forward slash, and a tax office employer reference, like 123/AB456. It may be called ‘Employer PAYE reference’ or ‘PAYE reference’.

sections.title: Agreement

fields.infoText: Read and agree to these principles before submitting. If we accept your application, you must follow these principles or we may stop the process at any time.

fields.label: mouDetail
fields.infoText:
- You and your representative must be available within 90 days for a face to face meeting. This may take a full day.

- If the mediator asks for more information, you need to provide this within 15 days

- If you discover new information before a meeting, you need to provide this to the mediator and the caseworker as quickly as possible 
 
- If you cannot meet any deadlines, you must tell the mediator

- The mediator will treat your information confidentially. This does not cover evidence of criminality, or facts that significantly change your tax or penalty situation.

- If you make a formal complaint about the process, the mediator will be asked to comment. This may include information you have told them confidentially.

choices: I confirm that I have read and agreed to these principles. I understand this does not guarantee my application will be accepted.

sections.title: Agreement

fields.infoText: Read these principles, and get your client's agreement to them before submitting. If we accept your application, you and your client must follow these principles or we may stop the process at any time.

fields.label: mouDetail
fields.infoText:
- You and your client must be available within 90 days for a face to face meeting. This may take a full day.

- If the mediator asks for more information, you need to provide this within 15 days

- If you discover new information before a meeting, you need to provide this to the mediator and the caseworker as quickly as possible 
 
- If you or your client cannot meet any deadlines, you must tell the mediator

- The mediator will treat your client's information confidentially. This does not cover evidence of criminality, or facts that significantly change your tax or penalty situation.

- If you make a formal complaint about the process, the mediator will be asked to comment. This may include information you or your client have told them confidentially.

choices: I confirm that I have explained these principles to my client and they have agreed to them. I understand this does not guarantee the application will be accepted.
